Jo Bennett

It may have escaped your notice but the Bishop was elected by his diocese, guided by the Holy Spirit. It is not a question of the Bishop doing anything. He is not going against the beliefs of his denomination, ECUSA allowed him to be appointed in full knowledge of his relationship and past. The difficulty has been with the wider Anglican communion, which is still undecided on this issue, which felt ECUSA was moving too fast and, more particularly, without proper consultation. There is a historic split in the Anglican church between liberal, evangelical and catholic factions, it just happens that on this a liberal wing of the church has moved too far too fast for the rest to keep up. There is nothing biblically to prohibit commited monogamous same sex relationships, and the Bishop has repented for the failure of his marriage.

 That's a nice sounding spin on it. But it takes wide-open interpretive gymnastics to come to the conclusion that God has no problem with homosexuality. This is not a matter of one group in the church changing too fast for the rest, it's an issue of one group rebelling against the broader Anglican community. The international Anglican church are the ones that are right, and the American episcopals (not all of them, just the ultra-liberal ones) are turning their backs on not only the authority of the church, but absolute truth as well. Their ethics have become situational and that's not a good position for the church to be in.
 
 Ultimately the real issue is whether or not Anglicans are going to believe the Bible means what it says, and whether we are going to water down our interpretations every time a group decides they want the sin they are commiting to be "ok with God and church."
 
 If the episcopal rebels had broken off from the larger Anglican community and started their own denomination that let's them do whatever they want no matter what the Bible says, that would have been fine. But they are insisting on changing the denomination, and therefore are trying to impose their views on the rest of them. As it is, they are in the process of being kicked out of the broader Anglican community. At this point, that's probably a good idea.

 I agree with Jo Bennet on this one; I believe that it takes selectively interpretive gymnastics to come to the Conclusion that God disapproves of homosexuality through the Bible. I don't know whether Jo is right about the incorrect interpretations from Hebrew of a word that is not actually "homosexual" but I do believe that one cannot follow the references opposing homosexuality in the Old Testament without also following a plethora of certainly evil activities, worst of which are cold-blooded murder and torture.
 
 It appears to me that most deep scholars of the Bibles believe that the teachings of the New Testament replaced those teachings of the Old Testament at some point except in where the teachings were reverified by the New Testament. They also tend to claim that condemnation of homosexuality is repeated in the New Testament, but the references are weak and interpretive. Many quote references to Sodom, but Sodom was destroyed for its oppression of the lower class. Many quote references to promiscuity, which of course has nothing to do with homosexuality.
 
 I may be missing some argument here; this is based on what I know of the Bible. But it seems to me that people only find condemnation of homosexuality in the Bible because they are looking for it.

If you read and really study Biblical interpretation and methods for any length of time, you find out real quick that it's pretty common for some people to use the "mistranslated" argument to make the scriptures say what they want them to say, especially when there are political and ideological motives as in the case of gay lobby groups. Besides, to throw out traditional interpretation just because it's politically advantageous to do so seems pretty desperate to me. 

 
 If it can be shown through reputable scholarship that a particular passage in the bible was mistranslated, how could you NOT want to know that? You would prefer the adulterated "Word of God" just for tradition's sake? Even more appalling is relying on a recent "modernized" translation. Frankly, I've always thought it odd that "true believers" would even touch a bible in contemporary English.
 
 
It seems to me it would be better to simply disagree with the Bible and accept that there is a disagreement than to try to reinterpret it and convince everyone that a sudden new reinterpretation (at least in the sense of this century--mostly the last 3 decades) is better than thousands of years of interpreting it the other way. 

 
 Modern day biblical scholarship is a vast improvement over the studies of the previous several hundred years. Any review of history shows that the translation process was rife with errors and impure motives, many based on political goals of the times. At least today, there is a world-wide, rigorous field of study.
 
 That said, though I find the ideas about misrepresentations of scripture interesting and worthy of real analysis, I don't expect any major revision. I find it entirely plausible, indeed likely that the writers of Leviticus and other books were just as bigoted against gay people as their modern-day counterparts. For them to be incapable of differentiating temple prostitution from same-sex love does not surprise me. For them to condemn a cultural practice of their arch enemies does not surprise me. Goodness knows, "god's chosen people" didn't like a whole lot of what the majority of the world was up to. (There's a recent Frontline episode on extremist Jewish settlers in the West Bank. In one scene, one of the leaders rants about "the Hellenists" that defile Israel -- something like that. These hatreds go back millennia -- we just got stuck in the middle.)
 
 
And since the reinterpretation comes up in times of a political and ideological push to make homosexual sex as acceptable as apple pie (really an outgrowth of the 60s sexual revolution), it comes across as pretty suspect.

 
 It has been shown to you over and over that the movement predates the "sexual revolution" of the 60s by about 80 years. I can only assume that sheer dishonesty and immorality lie behind your continuing misrepresentation of the roots of the gay rights movement.

 Nor have I ever run across a religiously anti-gay person who regretted  having to condemn gay people based on the Bible, perhaps realizing that such condemnation flies in the face of so many of Christ's teachings (indeed, I don't know what most of them would find to occupy their time if they couldn't  spend it actively condemning us), or one who, upon learning from some respected church authority that the scriptures don't  in fact censure us, wouldn't immediately switch churces to one that still believes they do.

 
 While we're at it, I've never met one anti-religion person who regretted the dishonesty of wrongly applying phrases like "condemn gay people," as if disagreement with any of their views was tantamount to condemnation. As if saying "I disagree that gay sex is ok" is condemning anyone.
 
 Come to think of it, I don't think I've ever even heard a sermon where gay people were truly condemned, period.
BobNelson2

(By the way, did you know the word "homosexual" never appeared in any English biblical translation before 1946?)

 
 Well, if the bible were indeed the revealed word of god for all the ages, it would be chock-full of words we didn't know, especially in the parts that talk about events of nature.
 
 But it isn't, so it isn't.
BobNelson2

Especially if you have to look up the original Hebrew and Greek meanings of words to make sense of the wide variences in translation. Not to mention having to reconcile all the contradictions...

 
 Actually, I'd find that more interesting than just reading it in English, though it would get tedious.
MrWriteLA

Actually, I'd find that more interesting than just reading it in English, though it would get tedious.
 I've always found it confusing that God--who is, after all, supposed to be perfect--would allow everyone to be left in such a state of confusion about what his Word is, what with so many of his "messengers" disagreeing and giving mixed mesages about it all the time. For being perfect, he certainly seems to have done a botch job in that department.
BobNelson2

Rest assured, every word of the Bible in what we have of the Hebrew Greek and Aramaic (not orginal copies, BTW) has been gone over with a fine-toothed comb many, many times, since Erasmus. 

 
 So, how come there are so many different versions?
 
 
Or maybe, just maybe, God told them to avoid gay sex and they were simply trying to obey Him. Maybe we should actually give them the benefit of the doubt that they were doing as they were told. (gasp! emoticon_wow )

 
 No chance of that. God, if it exists, doesn't tell people anything.
 
 Why should I give only the ancient Hebrews the benefit of the doubt about the universe? There are other competing religious traditions that are just as valid. Some are quite a bit more poetic. Goodness knows, there are more benign ones.
 
 On the other hand, I certainly encourage them, and members of all religious traditions, to live their lives according to their beliefs (with the previously mentioned restriction on causing physical harm to others).
 
 If only they would do me the same courtesy.
 
 
Not in any effective and notable sense, and you know it.

 
 This is so tedious. You just don't want to accept that our movement has a long history. 
 
 YOU may not find it notable that they stopped locking us up in the last century, but I do. I'm also darned grateful they stopped lobotomizing us. 
 
 Guess they must have gotten you.
BobNelson2

Come to think of it, I don't think I've ever even heard a sermon where gay people were truly condemned, period.

 
 Oh, your silly game again.
 
 Have you ever heard of a sermon where gay people were condemned?
BobNelson2

I've always found it confusing that God--who is, after all, supposed to be perfect--would allow everyone to be left in such a state of confusion about what his Word is, what with so many of his "messengers" disagreeing and giving mixed mesages about it all the time. For being perfect, he certainly seems to have done a botch job in that department.

 
 Typical overpaid CEO...
Jo Bennett

I fully agree that the translation may also be inaccurate, but the very fact that it is open to interpretation so extensively should surely call into question the traditional teaching about homosexuality. Just because something is traditional doesn't make it right. For a long time it was traditional to justify hatred and persecution of Jews by using the so called "blood libel" passage. Likewise slavery was justified by the bible. Racism was justified by Jesus calling cypriots dogs. Blocking women called to serve God was justified by some Pauline texts.
 
 jyoshu, could you possibly highlight what is wrong with the alternative translations I linked to? Beyond the fact that they differ from your own view.
 
 New translations are not "suspicious", biblical scholarship is improving constantly as more texts are foun and cross referenced. There are some words in the bible we are unable to translate still, and others still that may have had multiple meanings. Archaeology still turns up useful finds in the region, which add to our understanding.
jyoshu

Oh, your silly game again.
 
 Have you ever heard of a sermon where gay people were condemned?

 
 Game?
 
 I've heard of some preachers that indeed do--I think Fred Phelps epitomizes it well. Obviously he really does hate gay people. I don't know that I've heard of any specific sermon that condemned gay people.
jyoshu

I fully agree that the translation may also be inaccurate, but the very fact that it is open to interpretation so extensively should surely call into question the traditional teaching about homosexuality. Just because something is traditional doesn't make it right. For a long time it was traditional to justify hatred and persecution of Jews by using the so called "blood libel" passage. Likewise slavery was justified by the bible. Racism was justified by Jesus calling cypriots dogs. Blocking women called to serve God was justified by some Pauline texts.

 
 These are cases where people took their own prejudices to the scripture to find something that would justify it. In the case of gay people, there are lot's of people who are simply out to obey scripture, and therefore use it to set their moral guide.
 
 
jyoshu, could you possibly highlight what is wrong with the alternative translations I linked to? Beyond the fact that they differ from your own view.

 
 I've read that entire website long before you linked to it here. I'd have to do a vere-by-verse rebuttal to really do it justice, but suffice it to say the website doesn't really have any more valid view of those passages than the way it is commonly interpreted (to be about homosexuality). It also fails to take into account historical context in some cases.
 
 
New translations are not "suspicious", biblical scholarship is improving constantly as more texts are foun and cross referenced. There are some words in the bible we are unable to translate still, and others still that may have had multiple meanings. Archaeology still turns up useful finds in the region, which add to our understanding.

 
 Just because a translation is newer doesn't make it better. Accuracy isn't just in having access to manuscripts that go farther back (99% of the time they are identical to the ones that don't go as far back), but in being able understand them and compare them to the other manuscripts. 
 
 If the "recentness" of a translation was what made it the best, anyone could come out with any translation frought with errors and claim it was better than all the others. It's better to approach a new translation with suspicion and let it prove itself than to assume it's superior just because it's new.
wsm2506

It's interesting, isn't it, how the so-called "strongly-held beliefs" of so many people are actually the parroted, unquestioned, unexamined "strongly-held beliefs" of others, rather than a genuine, independently arrived at philosophy?

 
 I have come to a similar conclusion. When young children are taught from their first beginings of comprehension to blindly follow the religious dogma pounded into them repeatedly over their entire lives, by their parents and their particular religious denomination, they loose the ability to question, think, and reason independantly.
 
 This is the essence of brainwashing.
 
 It is interesting to note that anthrapological studies of societies which do not teach such dogmatic brainwashing, are relatively free of prejudice in general.
jyoshu

I have come to a similar conclusion. When young children are taught from their first beginings of comprehension to blindly follow the religious dogma pounded into them repeatedly over their entire lives, by their parents and their particular religious denomination, they loose the ability to question, think, and reason independantly.
 
 This is the essence of brainwashing.

 
 Sorry, but I'll teach my children right and wrong, rather than leave them to figure it all out for themselves, thank you. 
 
 "Son, why did you steal that? Don't you know it's bad to steal things?"
 
 "Sir, my parents never told me either way, and always said I should come to my own 'genuine, independently arrived at philosophy.'"
wsm2506

Sorry, but I'll teach my children right and wrong, rather than leave them to figure it all out for themselves, thank you. 
 
 "Son, don't you know it's bad to steal things?"
 
 "Sir, my parents never told me either way, and always said I should come to my own 'genuine, independently arrived at philosophy.'"

 
 You teach them what YOU were taught by YOUR religion and YOUR parents.
 
 Do you expose them to other religious beliefs? Do you teach them to keep an open mind and search for themselves? Or do you teach them blind obedience?
 
 What would you say to them when and if they came home from school after being exposed to the theory of evolution?
wsm2506

You sure have a knack for portraying opinion as imposition. We aren't even talking about "civil rights" in this thread, we are talking about Gene Robinson's insistence on going against church doctrine, even at the risk of tearing the church apart. His "civil rights" aren't being violated--he can still worship as he chooses. No one here is advocating a law against him being able to do that.

 
 The Reverend Robinson was duly elected by a majority the duly elected / appointed representatives of the see in which he serves. to be their bishop.
 
 I thought you were all for "majority rule" emoticon_frazzled
MrWriteLA

Personally, I'd rather my son realize why  stealing and murder are wrong through reason--rather than "because I said so." 
"Shake off all the fears of servile prejudices, under which weak minds are servilely crouched. Fix reason firmly in her seat, and call on her tribunal for every fact, every opinion. Question with boldness even the existence of a God; because, if there be one, he must more approve of the homage of reason than that of blindfolded fear."
 
 --Thomas Jefferson, letter to his nephew Peter Carr, Aug. 10, 1787
jyoshu

You teach them what YOU were taught by YOUR religion and YOUR parents.

 
 That's right--and unapologetically so. There are a lot of great lessons my parents taught me, as well as some good principles I've heard pastors teach. What's the problem? Why do you have such an aversion to any moral principles in parenting?
 
 
Do you expose them to other religious beliefs? 

 
 Nope, as of now. Maybe some down the road.
 
 
Do you teach them to keep an open mind and search for themselves? 

 
 Certainly, but that doesn't mean there can't be some basics that can be taught to them.
 
 
What would you say to them when and if they came home from school after being exposed to the theory of evolution?

 
 I'm a theistic evolutionist myself, so why would I have a problem with that?
